children.name: Lower Garden
description: The steeply overhanging, uber high off the deck front-side of the Meth Lab Boulder is typically the first formation to visually grab climbers off the road

Walking in from the parking lot at Mile point west to east the Lower Garden "Old" Access trailhead will be encountered first. If Fight Club, Undertow or Mini-Me are your aim, head up this first scramble, passing a too-short to climb Turtle in A Half Shell on the way with its distincitve crack splitting it. If your sights are set on Boys In the Woods, The Good V3 or Angry Grandma, continue past this first scramble to where Roadside Boulder and Toilet Bowl are easily visible with an easier trail entry. Many opt for the "New" trailhead simply for ease, especially if the ground is wet at all, as the "Old" access can be muddy and slippery.

children.name: Toilet Bowl
children.description: Sit start on positive underclings, initial power pull gives options to continue with underclings left or stab the right hand to small ledge of slopey goodness. The top presents a sloping but positive shelf with a mantle while avaoiding a large tree root.

children.name: Scrubbing Bubbles
children.description: Shared sit start with Toilet Bowl, avoiding the sloping shelf, veering left on underclings for both hands. This problem can top out with Toilet Bowl, or finish out traversing left with minor feet throughout.

children.name: P-Lunger
children.description: Sit start of this problem is made awkward by a small rock blocking the trail. Great holds, big moves, but a scary landing.

children.name: Project Roadside
children.description: An obvious sit start on the accessible portion of this boulder. This problem faces the road.

children.name: Project Roadside 2
children.description: There are room for two steep problems on this boulder.

children.name: Leonardo
children.description: Sit start from the bottom right hand corner. Continue by following an edge from Donatello to positive holds along the arete.

children.name: Donatello
children.description: Sit start right of Michelangelo. Power pull start move to snatch right edges and crimps to top out.

children.name: Michelangelo
children.description: Steep sit start. The crux is the first two moves with a slopey edge half way up the boulder.

children.name: Raphael Crack
children.description: Problem climbs on the obvious crack. Steep start in the cave, with first moves that are more awkard than hard.

children.name: Gumb
children.description: This problem is on the climber's left side of the boulder. A squat start suffices with positive holds throughout. Short.

children.name: ie
children.description: Climbs the right side of the boulder. The holds are even more positive than Gumb. Short.

children.name: Bitchin Corners
children.description: Bitching Corners warm up and Crack face the centerpiece Boys in the Woods Boulder. The steeper more quality flank fo Bitchin Corners is downhill, facing the road and accesses boulders #37 and #38 with bushwhack access to The Hueco Wall.

children.name: Bitchin Corners Warm Up
children.description: This slab is split by a horizontal crack and ledge. There are many ways to climb warm up on this slab. Your back is to Boys in the Woods boulder on this problem.

children.name: Bitchin Corners Crack
children.description: Holds in and out of the crack. There are warm up opportunities galore.

children.name: Claustrophobia
children.description: Climb insides of a cave for an uncomfortable start. Posturing the body in the chasm can be as difficult as the Bitchin Corners holds and moves.

children.name: Left Corner
children.description: Stand start on the left side of the south facing face of the boulder avoiding holds of Bitchin Corners. A quicker top out than Bitching Corners or Right Arete.

children.name: Bitchin Corners
children.description: The primary steller line of this boulder. An awkward sit start leads to a hidden jug under a protruding roof. Dangerous landing.

children.name: Right Arete
children.description: Climbs the ride side of face. The uphill stages a sit start with body wrapped around right corner. Roof of Bitchin Corners gets used as an undercling, but not traversed into for top out.

children.name: Ed's in the Woods
children.description: This problem is uphill and close to The Tonsil. In the break between an overhang. Full horizontal sit start. With extremely steep angle difficult hoolds. It's sure to challenge.

children.name: Boys in the Woods Left
children.description: Boys in the Woods sit start then veering left after pulling up to quality holds. The difficulty eases with an early top out, but can be finished with ?

children.name: Boys in the Woods
children.description: Quality sit start on great sloper holds, heels have options. Steep moves to odd palming mantle for direct finish. Good.

children.name: Boys in the Woods Right
children.description: Boys in the Woods sit start, veering right to quicker topout than Boys in the Woods left finish.

children.name: Cuba Gooding Jr.'s Air Punches
children.description: Sit start with distinctive full line avoiding Jerry Curl. The change of ? into holds makes different moves than Boys in the Woods Right.

children.name: Ice Cubes Shiny Jerry Curl
children.description: Steep sit start with a distictive full line avoiding Cuba Gooding. ? short stiff problem.

children.name: Odd Undercling
children.description: Sit start quick power gains a right hand to the ledge, while left hand maintains undercling. The arete above unlocks a right ? to the ledge, and ? top out.

children.name: Boys in the Woods
children.description: The primary problem. ? sit start power moves to the ledge. Mid-boulder, a mantle gains the top half holds.

children.name: No Ledge Face
children.description: Awkward sit start with bad landing. Angle and holds create ? ease, ? problem.

children.name: Tongue Depressor
children.description: Stand start climbers left of the more obvious holds for The Tonsil. A crux crimp ?.

children.name: The Tonsil
children.description: Stand start, kicking legs high off interesting start holds. A test piece, despite no ?.

children.name: All Sorts of Ease
children.description: A lean prominent face on the south or road facing flank, with available right and left arete, with crimps on the face.

children.name: Walking the Dog
children.description: Climbs right of All Sorts of Ease. This left side of the large lower slab, under the overhang of the Meth Lab front, offers a fun problem.

children.name: Slabbing in the Shadow of Giants
children.description: Right of Walking the Dog, a stand start with goodl holds and a bad landing gains top after two moves.

children.name: More Ease
children.description: Located on the backside or flank of All Sorts of Ease facing The Bubbler. Easy and in the shade.

children.name: Even More Ease
children.description: Like More Ease, on the Bubbler flank of All Sorts of Ease. Warm up ready.

children.name: Not Yet Done
children.description: A steep sit / lay start in a cave, 10 feet to the climbers left of Leave It To Jesus. There are holds present, but a minor dry season window. Top out may not be necessary, ?

children.name: Southie's Northern Odub
children.description: A varying size off-width crack. The same crack on the boulder's opposite flank is a walk up and ?.

children.name: Not Yet Done
children.description: Like the other undone in this cave, a steep path with holds present a real potential.

children.name: Leave it to Jesus
children.description: THis problem is on an uphill slightly overhanging wall with a better than usual landing. Crimps and distinctive edges tend directly up the face with no arete help. A quality problem. Slight uphill and around the corner to the right is the enterance to the Meth Lab.

children.name: Smack Down
children.description: A steep sit start into a line to mantle on the far left side of the cave. Limited dry months for this and other Meth Lab problems.

children.name: Heisenberg
children.description: Another steep sit start climbs right of Smack Down. A full quality full line with limited dry time like Smack Down and Meth Myth.

children.name: Meth Myth
children.description: A steep sit start that eventually veers left to finish with different top outs ?.

children.name: Leary's Lunge
children.description: A long stretch breaks up obvious holds for a low sit start to head high sloping edges.

children.name: Meth Lab Dyno
children.description: Stand start into positive holds, with quality moves to the obvious ledge. Once the ledge is established, ?. Mantling on the ledge then topping out beyond the ledge is a standard V1 finish.

children.name: Meth Lab Dyno Sit
children.description: Sit start or lay starting into the obvious lower cave ups the difficulty substantially. Finishing with a ? left or a ? right ? the ledge also changes the difficulty.

children.name: Tom's Psychedelic Trip
children.description: Start on Meth Lab Dyno Sit ?, then continues traversing left, utilizing holds through Heisenberg, Meth Myth, Leary's Lunge and Meth Lab Dyno and the ledge. Can be topped out at multiple points, adjusting the difficulty, depends on finish.

children.name: Right Finish, Meth Lab Dyno
children.description: Start on Meth Lab Dyno's start, after the midpoint ledge, veer right and around right to the ? the tall face ? left of Acacia Berlandieri.

children.name: Right Finish, Meth Lab Dyno Sit
children.description: Same as other right finish but start on Meth Lab Dyno Sit.

children.name: Acacia Berlandieri
children.description: ? stand start on ? just under vert tall wall. Fun ? rarely dry.

children.name: Descent
children.description: Easy chimney descent with only moss creating difficulty. Opposite side of ? Southie's Northern O-dub.

children.name: Uphill of Boys in the Woods
Slab
children.description: This low angle problem starts on the Boys in the Woods side of tree adjacent to this boulder. The problem is fairly tall for as a bad a ? as it has.

children.name: TBD ?
children.description: Steep sit start problem. Never seen it dry or clean of moss.

children.name: TBD ?
children.description: Steep sit start problem. Never seen it dry or clean of moss.

children.name: The Bubbler
children.description: A quality test-piece. Starts with a steep sit / lay, powering through cruxy holds and moves.

children.name: Sherlock
children.description: Quality, comparable in difficulty to The Bubbler with different holds, simular steepness.

children.name: Chillum
children.description: Stand start due to awkward bottom block. Better holds than The Bubbler.

children.name: Crawl Before You Walk
children.description: Short, low-angle left over a hump from primary problems. Warm-up.

children.name: Warm-Up
children.description: Trailside stand start on 3 or 4 move warm-up problem. Good holds, low angle.

children.name: Warm-Up 2
children.description: To the climbers left of Warm-Up, climbing towards The Office. Simular to The Warm-up.

children.name: Hidden Warm-Up
children.description: Tucked opposite side of spire as The Office, facing The Bubbler. A touch harder than The Warm-Up or The Warm-Up 2 due to slightly stiffer holds, less moves though.

children.name: Get Out of My Nook
children.description: Minor sit start problem on a minor block located on the secondary side of The Office next to Warm-Up Spire, downhill from Bubbler. Problem is short, but holds are interesting.

children.name: Dwight
children.description: Tucked between The Annex and Warm-Up Spire, this tand start slab has some testy holds and moves for low angle. Can be fun, always needs to be cleaned.

children.name: Kelly Kapoor
children.description: Test-piece sit start on very small holds. Angles seem conducive but holds are slight.

children.name: Ryan "the Temp"
children.description: Simular to Kelly Kapoor, wrestling the arete brings difficulty down slightly.

children.name: Office Descent
children.description: Decent enough warm-up to harder projects, a reasonable descent, an alternative to descending here would be to boulder hop over Fight Club to Trust Boulder and walk-off.

children.name: Jim Halbert
children.description: Stand start into decent holds. The landing gets worse as you veer slightly left. Holds get better when they need to.

children.name: Michael Scott
children.description: More difficult line than Jim Halbert or Daryl Philbin, but with a better landing. Quality.

children.name: Daryl Philbin
children.description: Stand into positive holds. Quality holds throughout. High.

children.name: Toby Flenderson Traverse
children.description: Good warm-up for area. Can go either direction, utilizing holds at different heights for variations.

children.name: Vince
children.description: If this problem / boulder didn't have a horrible landing, it would be as clean as Fight Club stays. Quality Garden Variety holds on a slight angle. Good height, bad landing.

children.name: Larry
children.description: Same attributes as Vince, stand start on slightly more vert angle. Interesting holds.

children.name: Don't Be A Dummy, Pad Up
children.description: Stand start into semi-vert that quickly bowls, then turns into vert again. Falling may pitch you into Fight Club.

children.name: Bloody Knuckles Crack
children.description: Wide crack that can start seated or standing, left arm in or right.

children.name: Bloody Knuckles
children.description: Sit start utilizing holds to the inside of the crack on Fight Club. Holds and movement will orient the body tight to the crack, mitigating steepness.

children.name: Cacophony Society
children.description: Sit start on positive holds avoiding holds internal to the crack. After the first move the boulder's angle pulls the climber slightly left, then quickly finishing on positive finishing holds.

children.name: Ubermensch
children.description: After shared sit start with Cacophony Society a big move low and left gains a semi positive hold. A heel and body shift positive to gain decent intermediate holds connecting to a manageable top-out.

children.name: Uber
children.description: In suit with Ubermensch, but avoids immediate upward movement after balancing out to first reach hold. Continue veering left for an even harder varient of Ubermensch.

children.name: Fight Club
children.description: High quality area test-piece! Lay start separate from Cacophony Society, Ubermensch and Uber sit start. Stays on steep angled face with distinctive "pop-corn" holds. Heels can help but difficult holds up.

children.name: Fight Club 2
children.description: Lay start, same face and steepness of Fight Club, different holds hedging left.

children.name: Brewmaster
children.description: Sit start retaining tension to less steep face, working positive hold to positive hold through powerful moves. A hidden pocket at 3/4 height can help sort out finish. Suprisingly approachable for an otherwise unapproachable boulder.

children.name: Durden Crack
children.description: Stand start into crack utilizing jams and holds. Goes facing both directions.

children.name: Durden Lie-back
children.description: Stand start into positive holds peppering the arete, lie-backing on positive holds through mantle. Avoid the crack. Bad landing for a decent height top-out. Crimp of Tyler Durden and Project Mayhem not needed.

children.name: Tyler Durden
children.description: This difficulty on just under vert is hard to find. An obvious matched crimp start makes for a squat start on low dime feet. A thin horizontal crack indicates a poor but necessary hold.

children.name: Project Mayhem
children.description: Established squat / stand start on the same crimp as Tyler Durden, veering left for better feet. Beyond first couple moves difficulty eases as feet become reasonable. Easy top-out, bad landing.

children.name: Trust
children.description: Low cave sit start on positive holds. The right hand hits jugs on the arete to the right while the left centers through positive holds that turn into large matching jugs. These large jugs make for step up to high reach for positive crack systems lined with positive locks. This reach is the "Trust" move, have faith for positivity. A multitude of variants taking away psotive holds from start through middle to finish.

children.name: Iron Cross
children.description: Shared cave sit as Trust, avoiding right arete the right hand goes to a distinctive sloper hold just below jug. Locking this sloper veer out left to gaston, completely avoiding positive jugs. Crossing over to boulder's left side for easier, less committing top-out. Harder but less committing up high.

children.name: Mr. Bigglesworth
children.description: Sit start bottom left of big face. Positive holds throughout, tensioning to arete to alleviate steepness. Multiple eliminates and variations including linking sit start of into top-out of Number 2 and Austin Powers.

children.name: Dr. Evil
children.description: Stiffer sit start than Mr. Bigglesworth as you slide left. Avoid positive holds on arete staying center to face.

children.name: KISS (Knights In The Servcie of Steve (Nelson))
children.description: Notable eliminate. Think SLOPERS! Sit start to big move to sloper on arete. Matching this out can be cruxy. So many eliminates on this face...

children.name: Number 2
children.description: Shared sit start with Dr. Evil veering left to holds utilized for Austin Powers. Stiff but manageable. Quality mantle technique top-out.

children.name: Shagadellic Traverse
children.description: Sit start bottom left arete, just right of Mini-Me sit start. After start veer drastically right to holds of Dr. Evil. Lots of footwork. Finish harder or easier using or avoiding arete for top-out.

children.name: Austin Powers
children.description: Same sit start as Shagadellic Traverse but head directly up. Quality moves, lip comes quickly.

children.name: Mini-Me
children.description: Great problem, bad landing. Awkward squat / semi-sit start or stand into tenuous holds, quickly gaining edge on upper slab. Just because slab is reached, technical difficulty is not over. Take time over horrible landing balancing out top-out.

children.name: Felicity Shagwell
children.description: Separate line of Mini-me, but shares many qualities including bad landing, awkward start and tenuous holds. Quality movement for such a short side of a boulder.

children.name: A Good V2
children.description: Sit start climber's right side of steep cave. Steep powerful moves ending quickly to mantle and top-out off slopey ledge less than 5 feet off deck.

children.name: Another Good V2
children.description: Sit start climber's left side of cave. Simuplar in nature to A Good V2, but with more interesting holds. Couple different ways of going about problem, difficulty maintains.

children.name: E's Dirty B
children.description: Sit start in the hold. Different body types different feet, popcorn holds, both undercling and at the mouth of cave. Quick strenuous moves where steepness turns to vert. Easy top-out.

children.name: E's Dirty B (Right Finish)
children.description: Same sit start as E's Dirty B, after vert is gained, veer right for different midpoint holds and different top-out. Changes difficulty little.

children.name: Blame It On The Rain
children.description: Left side of the cave has diverse feet and hands to E's Dirty B (Right Finish), and naturally heads more centered left to a shelf shortly off the deck. From the shelf top-out is easy.

children.name: Green Hell
children.description: Sit start so awkward and landing so bad this problem is rarely cleaned / climbed. The uphill takes height away from an already short boulder, but the holds are slighly better than E's Dirty B (Right Finish) and Blame It On The Rain making it good for warm-up to these harder lines.

children.name: Spray Skirt
children.description: Sit start extreme left of boulder almost under Silly Steep is actually easier than sit start for Undertow. Beyond intermediates 3-4 moves high it would seem holds end. A crimp at boulder's 3/4 height unlocked by large move leads to top-out.

children.name: Spray Against the Undertow
children.description: Sit start of Spray Skirt, veering right with and linking into positive hold marking the end of Undertow's difficulty. Interesting and fun in its own right, great problem for building up to Undertow.

children.name: Undertow
children.description: High quality test-piece! Sit start in steep scoop. Quick powerful moves eventually gain a jug 6 feet off the deck. From this jug difficulty eases. The top-out is V1- and is often undone due to moss.

children.name: Shake It Out
children.description: If boulder wasn't beneath, would be great problem. Sit start right of Undertow, veering right then straight up through positive holds.

children.name: Simple Math
children.description: Shared sit start with Shake It Out, following a line of positive holds and relieved angle.

children.name: Tide Pool
children.description: Sit start is more doable than moves beyond. Seemingly blank faces yields minor crimps, pockets and edges.

children.name: Silly Steep Mantle
children.description: No feet start. Couple ways to skin a cat, heading left or right, it all requires campus moves to start, then introduce high feet under roof. Physical mantle.

children.name: 150 Ram
children.description: Sit start grappling the corner arete protruding on left flank of road-facing aspect.

children.name: 2 Ton Chevy
children.description: Sit start between bad landing blocks. Turns to vert quickly with positive holds.

children.name: Pup Truck
children.description: Sit start is awkward due to angle, positive holds quickly.

children.name: Radeo
children.description: Stand into goold holds. Basic warm-up problem.

children.name: La Machina de Luna
children.description: Into the stem from stand start. Any difficulty eases quick with good holds.

children.name: E's V7
children.description: Obvious low sit start starting directly into steepness on minute holds. The angle turns to vert then low angle 1/2 way up boulder. Behind this boulder a series of caves host mystery problems.

children.name: Near Meth Lab
children.description: Never been clean.

children.name: Meth Lab High-ball
children.description: A bad landing makes a short high-ball seem higher. Stand start.

children.name: Swollen Member
children.description: Lay start under contrived roof cave, slapping horizontally out and around bulge to quick mantle top-out. Difficulty simular to the physical nature of Silly Steep Mantle.

children.name: MotorArete
children.description: Suprisingly quality steep sit start that ends too quick. Transitioning from steep to slab is one interesting set of holds.

children.name: Motorhead
children.description: Primary line, taking on the overhung face, avoiding the arete of MotorArete. Landing sucks.

children.name: MotorMouth
children.description: Stand start on downhill slide to Swollen Member the problem has amazing difficulty for a more generous angle of the boulder, due to not so positive holds.

children.name: Next to the Good V3
children.description: Squaty sit start with obvious holds coming out of small cave. Difficulty doesn't necessarily ease with angle. Low angle top-out finish completed by pinching arete.

children.name: The Good V3
children.description: High quality test-piece! Stand into large matching jug, walking dimes to set up a high reach with the left hand. Matching and balancing out, the feet come up to set up one more simular high reach, this time to a smaller cruxier hold. This high dishy sloper unlocks the end top-out sequence. Classic!

children.name: Early Exit
children.description: Shared start with The Good V3. Beyond 1st crux, a reach out right reveals a wrong-way jug. Slowly hedging into the jug unlocks an easier second crux and quicker top-out.

children.name: Another V3
children.description: Rarely cleaned, this companion to The Good V3 suffers the same foothold breaking issues that The Good V3 suffers, resulting in variance to difficulty over the years.

children.name: Cookie Monster
children.description: Kid's problem. Easy beyond easy warm-up.

children.name: Abby Caddaby
children.description: Kid's problem. Easy beyond easy warm-up.

children.name: Spot Me Elmo
children.description: Kid's problem. Easy beyond easy warm-up.

children.name: The Orb
children.description: The tucked in problem is accessed by scrambling into cave below hanging boulder with large obvious Orb hold visible from the trail. A matched start on positive holds below the Orb hold quickly has you steep to start. Matching into the Orb hold, brings the feet high for a reach to the lip. Mantle top-out.

children.name: Baldinator
children.description: Squat start or awkward sit start into decent holds, the right finding holds outside of the crack. Veering left with the crack system, this problem involves decent handholds with dime feet. Once the feet gain the crack difficulty eases through top-out.

children.name: Frontside Baldo
children.description: Sit start with options for holds. By the time holds get limited the angle is eased.

children.name: Baldo Sit
children.description: Slightly downhill an obvious low start tackles the steep downhill arete not blocked by trees.

children.name: Dan Dee's Phishing Buddy
children.description: The one exposed flank of the boulder not blocked by trees or other boulders offers a quality sit start through physical moves on semi-positive holds. Horrible landing.

children.name: Dan Dee's Roof
children.description: Angle of kicker block makes for awkward sit-start. Handholds just above break transition to blocky set of jugs just under roof. From jugs veer right and out steep roof with holds on arete. Top-out comes after mantling lip of roof. Scary mantle.

children.name: Dan Dee's Arete
children.description: Sit start, work up the arete via positive holds on either side. Angle eases for top-out.

children.name: Not So Hueco
children.description: Sit start has a smaller cave to slide into than Yellowbottom, Hueco Wabo or Hueco Project. Can be stood into as well, this problem follows crimps, edges and cruxy holds avoiding the relief of the large ledge and jugs of A Cruel Dance.

children.name: A Cruel Dance
children.description: Sit start veering right for obvious ledge with positive mantle where problem's steepness ends. Low angle above is reasonable when cleaned of moss, which is rare.

children.name: Yellowbottom
children.description: Sit start out of lowest cave, making tenuous moves over worst of landings to connect with positive bulge and ledge implemented in A Cruel Dance. Minus poor landing block this problem would be a gem.

children.name: Hueco Wabo
children.description: Sit start in large lower cave with series of huecos, underclinging slopers and pinches. The line of holds running up the just over vert wall seems to run short on holds, but edges and crimps link to a lower angle arete top-out.

children.name: Hueco Project
children.description: Simular sit start to A Cruel Dance slid over climber's right a set of holds, this line quickly runs out of holds on a blank vert wall. The landing is quite reasonable for the Garden.

children.name: Hueco Warm-Up Left
children.description: Sit start with positive holds. Few moves from sit to mantle.

children.name: Hueco Warm-Up Right
children.description: Sit start, short like Hueco Warm-Up Left. Look for dish hidden under horizontal crack.

children.name: Big Slab
children.description: Large stand into slab with decen tlandings. During lat 90's - early 2000's this slab managed to stay clean and climbable. Moss perpetually sets in. Top offers great views of area.

children.name: Tree Slab
children.description: Divots, shallow pockets and edges, simular to Big Slab. If cleaned, this large slab offers many variants and alternative practice problems.

children.name: Pockets
children.description: Awkward sit start or squat into first set of pockets. Angle immediately slabs, so once the second and third set of pockets are gained difficulty eases. Avoid crack to climber's right.

children.name: All Berned Up
children.description: Quality test-piece! Almost dead horizontal knife edge flake peppered with minor holds on both sides. Feet are present on both sides of flake. This line has seen few sends. When facing this problem, your back is the Big Boulders Shed-Off.

children.name: Obie
children.description: A rise uphill in the landing prevents sit start, stand into good holds. Veering slightly right to the distinctive jug matched on Bruno can be reached with the right, unlocking top-out.

children.name: Bruno
children.description: Sit start powering to and past distinctive large positive hold visible in photo. Center flank of wall with no arete relief.

children.name: Classique
children.description: Quality line. The right arete hosts quality holds with a fun and not-so awkward sit start. The landing will feel claustrophobic with the V10 Cave at your back.

children.name: Crazy Cool Arete
children.description: Isolated block. Sit start wrapped around the arete. Doable moves on precise, less than positive holds. Veer slightly left away from arete for top-out.

children.name: Sharma Cave
children.description: Steep pure line starting low in cave, containing many moves and parts, eventually topping out high over bad landing. Interesting holds in a cave that rarely gets wet or mossy.

children.name: Sometimes a Great Motion
children.description: A quality line, exceptional for its grade, tucked between the Off-Vert section and Crazy (Steep) Cave of Big Boulder. At halfway mark and above interesting holds for every move! Being in transitional area the landing is much less than desirable.

children.name: Big Stem
children.description: A quality line tucked between the more obvious Sometimes A Great Motion and Mini-Hydrotube. Sit start moves through cruxy handholds and smears until a set of stems unlocks the first of many positive holds are met. These positive holds connect to an easy top-out.

children.name: Mini-Hydrotube
children.description: Unlike Flagstone's Hydrotube this line gets lots of moss re-growth due to water line, and has big obvious holds. Sit start can seem awkward because angle's less than steep. When cleaned, holds are positive.

children.name: Eric and Ed Probably Did it
children.description: Difficulty project line, tackling a steep line of small holds to the left side of the cave. Sit start committing to only v-difficult holds, avoiding crack system of Becky's Roof Start.

children.name: Becky's Roof Start
children.description: Standing start stemming the cave, blending overhead jams and hand-holds. Once angle eases difficulty is done.
children.history: Around the corner from Becky's Roof Start and before "The Shed Off" there lies two sit starts, to full lines that have been cleaned in the past by the author. Coinciding with this cleaning of said projects the author discovered the Druid Stons. These lines were never sent, see Druid Stones guidebook.

children.name: Off Vert Wall Warm-Up
children.description: Sit start utilizing some of the only positive holds on Big. Great way to access top for cleaning / top-roping.

children.name: Slopodon Milosevic
children.description: Left to right or right to left, this traverse maintains with feet less than 5 feet off the deck, controlling semi-low angle movement through a series of sloper holds, smears for feet with only the occasional pinch or divot for rest. Cruxy transitioning in and out of Francois' Arete. Many variant ways of going about traverse including slight variations on height.

children.name: O Trice
children.description: Walking into holds of SLopodon extending into full vertical line. Angle eases at 11 feet height with positive holds for transition. High-ball, can be t/red with Family Affair tree. Crux in first 10 feet.

children.name: Joey
children.description: Starts with O Trice's stand start, veering drastic right into Shake It Out following opening crux. Follows bulge.

children.name: Shake It Out
children.description: Simular in nature to O Trice and Joey, but with some of the more positive holds, especially at 8-10 feet height.

children.name: Got Some Teeth
children.description: While the angle lends more positively than O Trice, Joey and Shake It Out, the holds tend to be smaller, sharper and cruxier and an otherwise simular slab.

children.name: Family Affair
children.description: Big low angle slab on the corner of Big Fred facing Angry Grandma.
children.history: In 2005-2006 a family man from Salem established an anchor on tree sprouting out of Big Fred and cleaned this slab completely for top-roping with his kids. This opened up a series of low angle routes on this easiest side of Fred's. Tat is likely still present on anchor tree.

children.name: Backside Baldo
children.description: Quality gem, tucked in an odd corner of Big Fred. Sit start on positive holds links to less positive intermediate holds verring right up the arete. A positive hold a few moves in allows for stiff mantle onto ease of Family Affair Slab. Top-out is big, and difficulty eases beyond mantle to slab.

children.name: Backside
children.description: Scrambling uphill from The Good V3, Ed's Arete is the first thing in view. Heading left at this fork puts you at Azain Crack Side, veering right continues onto Big Fred, Angry Grandma or the Hula Side of Azain.

children.name: Ed's Arete
children.description: Quality test piece. Brilliant climbing on thin edges, smears, dimes, all the works of an ultra-intense just off-vert wall. With height comes more positive holds, but the lower portions offer variants, eliminates and traverses abound.

children.name: Wash the Dishes
children.description: Stand start, tucked between Ed's Arete and Picking-Pockets. Low, simular holds and difficult to Ed's but handholds are slightly more positive, with more positive-ness up high.

children.name: Picking-Pockets
children.description: Stand into edges and crimps, only to be greeted with ultra positive pockets, jugs and a left veering seem. Staying with thin seam or not, top-out will continue on positive holds.

children.name: Kill Your Heros
children.description: Only poor landing on the wall, with blocks below. This stand start splits the difference between the well-defined Azain Crack and Picking-Pockets.

children.name: Azain Crack
children.description: Area standard. Quality bouldering moves from a stand start into a crack offering slick jams and holds that disappear. Beyond crack positive holds, and alternative thinner seams pick up. This climb, despite its recent bolting (along with the end of Big Fred) can be protected on natural gear (i.e. nuts and cams). Bolt(s) can be found on top as an alternative to small trees for anchoring.

children.name: Into the Light
children.description: Subterranean cave problem 6 or 7 feet climbs left and below Azain Crack. 5.5 climbing to get in and out of the cave. The problem tackles an obvious overhang with quality Garden Faire: Crimps, edges, divots, etc... Beware of critters, glass and waste. If cave exploring is the goal, a set of caves on the opposite side of Azain, uphill of Meth Lab are much more interesting for exploring and host boulder problems as well.

children.name: Mauritania
children.description: Standing into easier angle and holds than neighboring Ed's Arete, this line can top-out Azain or veer slightly right after intial crux to utilize the false top of Blues From Down Here and Staring at the Sun.

children.name: Blues From Down Here
children.description: This low angle portion of Azain offers a false top-out 11 feet off the deck. From this ledge climbing can continue on lower angle up to Azain's top and bolts for Crack and road-facing flank of Azain. Other than being approachable in its grade this problem stands out little.

children.name: Staring at the Sun
children.description: Simular to Blues form Down Here, with different holds. A distinct pocket makes for a great set-up hold. This line ends closer to small shrub.

children.name: Hula Slab
children.description: Wandering path of least resistance up larger tier of big slab. Functional in setting up top-rope, although walking around via Gumby Slab may be easier. If the entire slab was clean, wouldn't be bad for top-roping ease.

children.name: Hula Chimney
children.description: Mossy off-width climbing, starting with extremely wide body stemming, the crack eventually chokes down. This cave will connect into other Azain Caves.

children.name: Hula
children.description: Quality testpiece! Great moves and holds from a low sit start to hair-raising high-ball top-out! Low starting around a corner below right arete a powerful butt start veers left to long reaches for positive 5 finger edges. Balancing out following big moves can be early crux, folowed by a series of two deadpoints / dynos veering slightly back right. After the second move, eye down the arete. Once positive holds are established on the arete difficulty eases. Tall but manageable top-out can be pre-rehearsed utilizing a top-rope. Many hop down from arete especially if moss is present, as the top-out is rarely scrubbed up after 2005.
children.history: Ground zero for the 90's bouldering movement of the Garden.

children.name: Psychodork
children.description: Great problem with iffy landing. not as bad as the neighboring Oregon Arete for landings, but the lack of space below Psychodork is less than desirable. Potential sit start would be harder than the 4+/5- destinction. Stand start stretched hand to hand, stepping into dimes. On edge moves straight up the arete finish shared with hula on the flip side.

children.name: Oregon Arete
children.description: Beyond aesthetics, whether sit started or stood into, this problem is excellent, expect its landing. Not only does a large ground boulder block passage into the Full Stroke Cave, it is the landing for the Oregon Arete. Without poor landing this problem would be cleaned and climbed constantly, classic!

children.name: Eskimo Roll
children.description: Head high holds are mcuh easier to transition into via Full Stroke's start, a la Dog Paddle problem Oregon Arete. Sit start and end of this focused problem, avoiding Oregon Arete and Full Stroke makes for extreme end difficulty. Rarely cleaned of moss, versus Full Stroke stays clean from frequent traffic.

children.name: Full Stroke
children.description: Quality test-piece at an extremely reasonable grade. Sit start on positive jug holds, sticking your feet into often soacked water drainage crack. A powerful deadpoint with the left gains a large, sharp open handed jug. Locking this off moves the feet higher into the crack to a foot jam. This jam, with the jug gains a right hand jug veering right. Rest, one more big move horizontally right gains another positive monkey hang jug. Either jump down from here or stem into positive feet and finish the easy but often dirty and mossy top-out.

children.name: Dog Paddle
children.description: Start into Full Stroke's sit start and first move. Veer left into intermediate holds of Eskimo Roll finishing with Oregon Arete's top-out. Can seem contrived but is a good transition towards sending Eskimo Roll, gaining familiarity with holds.

children.name: 2 Pad Start
children.description: Obscure, but high quality and often climbed. Large portion of the cave presents rediculously steep and hold-less terrain. In the middle of this, 6-7 feet off the deck a set of starting holds present! stacking two to three pads can access the stand start, kciking into dime feet and edges and powering through sheer vert above the steepness. The top-out is rarely completely clear of moss.

children.name: The Other Bernd V10
children.description: Flank of rock left of crack. Obvious feet and hand holds are also obviously unusable to the mortal boulderer. Impressive aesthetic line with rails of slope and only minute edges and crimps present. May or may not top-out through face moves, may traverse into Soule Did It to walk-off.

children.name: Soule Did It Off Width
children.description: Misplaced Moolack cruz! Wide crack with stacked fists, hips and elbows. It's all in, chicken wings, knee bars - whatever odd twist of your limbs that make it work. Try and have fun, and if you do - you're weird. (See Moolack Guide, join us in off-width weirdness).

children.name: Godfry's Grovel Roof
children.description: Classic! Steep sit start on positive fun holds heading slightly right, then back left to hook up with distinct corner holds on arete below grovel roof. Crux begins once gaston corner is gained, with controlled power moves with small feet to gain sloper lip. Top-out mantle involving slopey lip. Many find the start of this problem very user friendly, only to get shut down as angle verts and holds loose positivity.

children.name: Bag of Tricks
children.description: Fun! Start on Godfry's sit start, gaining positive ledge two moves in. Instead of veering left into Godfry's crux, veer right into positive holds traversing right. The ledge gains Azain's Gumby Slab. An undercling at knee height, or high reach for positive incut jug is two ways of going about the transition onto the slab. Once on Gumby Slab, the natural inclination is to top-out on Gumby Mantle.

children.name: Gumby Arete
children.description: Low sit start utilizing undercling to connect positive holds to jug. From jug, tenuous slab top-out that is rarely cleaned of moss. If not clean, it is possible to transition onto Gumby Slab to top-out.

children.name: Gumby Slab
children.description: Standing into slab, picking between a handful of holds, a large positive ledge with jugs is quickly met. mantling this ledge sets up a choice of top-outs - veering left or right. Ledge can complicate a fall from above, commit and finish top-out or jump down from mid-ledge.

children.name: Gumby Crack
children.description: The fun for this climb starts after the easy sit start and low power moves in the crack. At half height a top-out slab section offers a more difficult section.

children.name: Slopey Sally
children.description: Rarely cleaned thoroughly in 2009, this entire slab is broken up by a large horizontal crack, making everything easy. Eliminating the crack creates difficulty. Top portion through a series of interesting slopers is better served without the crack.

children.name: Eric and Ed Did It
children.description: Oregon's mossy Atari! Sit start wrestling both sides of the arete on tweeky holds. Uber steep, with dynamic moves for some. Top-out can end lower than the entire Azain formation with a flat ending 12-14 feet off. Landing is bad, but not the Garden's worst.

children.name: Bat Cave T/R Left
children.description: Top-roping the inner left mouth of the Bat Cave is met with large feature holds with big movement between. Very exciting climbing. Careful on falls, for swings into alternate side of cave.

children.name: Bat Cave T/R Right
children.description: Simular to the Left, alternate side of the mouth. Rappelling this entire line dumps you into the Into The Light cave.

children.name: Spire Sit-Down
children.description: Sit start through minor steep portion or Spire. Eases after bulge.

children.name: Snakes and Martyrs
children.description: Warm-up on the Spire. Not a very tall spire, great opportunity to use interesting Garden holds on low angle.

children.name: Soul Wars
children.description: Simular to Snakes and Martyrs but different holds, and worse landing.

children.name: Chockstone High-ball
children.description: Quality high-ball test-piece for its grade! Quality holds! Exhilarating finish! Sit start in cave portion of boulder directly below large roof.

children.name: Chockstone Crack
children.description: Dirty. Holds and jams are easy. Can be helpful to clean holds for Chockstone High-ball.

children.name: Chockstone Arete Steep
children.description: Quality problem with worst landing. Steep sit start veering left through powerful moves from start. Stemming end eases difficulty of 2nd crux.

children.name: Chockstone Arete Slab
children.description: Stand starting into corner offers most difficulty of Chockstone Slab. Some holds tricky, but climbing maintains ease.

children.name: We Own The Sky
children.description: Stem problem, with pillar of Chockstone Arete Slab to the left and positivity to the right.

children.name: Midnight City
children.description: Low angle slab with positive holds galore.

children.name: Audience of One
children.description: See Midnight City.

children.name: Angus
children.description: See Midnight City.

children.name: Pelton Problem
children.description: Decent problem. On the Gumby Slab side of Chockstone High-ball, this problem is easily overlooked. Squatty sit start into interesting holds. Holding body tension is only crux.

children.name: Grandma Ridge
children.description: Stand start into easy ridge climbing with positivity of top holds.

children.name: Angry Mom
children.description: Quality problem. Standing into just off dead vert wall. First good holds are halfway up. Connect to Ridge for longer top-out.

children.name: Hop on Grand-pop
children.description: Standing left of ground shrub, moving right to start over the top of it quickly accesses top vert wall shared with Angry Mom. Little for sit start, this tall problem is over danger zone.

children.name: Angry Me-Maw
children.description: Worst landing. Bulge that creates stem for Angry Grandma start can be started low as a sit start. Once bulge is tackled V1++ high-ball vert climbing over horrible landing.

children.name: Angry Grandma
children.description: High quality test-piece! Walk into stem between bulge and wall to snag edges. An early V3 crux links semi-positive holds veering drastically left. The V6 section kicks in linking powerful moves through crimpy cruxy holds at height. The first ascent of this problem was admirably completed solo, after working with pad and spotter. It is possible to top-rope with trees on backside.

children.name: Ed's Cave
children.description: Single quality steep problem hidden in the gap between two boulders adjacent to Angry Grandma. Trail walks downhill into boulders with adequate space for sit start.

children.name: Rabid Squirrel
children.description: Facing Angry Grandma, this single line presents a quality sit start into interesting edges and slopers. Holds near top are great for lock and mantle for top-out.

children.name: Out of a Cave Azain
children.description: This "problem" climbs more like a route with its crack, length, and ability to step off at multiple points. This boulder is adjacent to Azain Boulder hosts a series of mysterious caves that have a history of bouldering problems, with little information known about them.

children.name: Blubonic Plague
children.description: Low sit start through mid-boulder to great incut slopers for mantle top-out.

children.name: The All or Nothing Days
children.description: Small holds broken up by the occasional positivity and small ledge. Stand into lie-backing small seam crack, this crack will disappear as angle eases towards top-out.

children.name: Seams High
children.description: Sit start off small pocks, divots, pockets and edges. The seam crack on this line won't pick up until 3/4 height or taller.

children.name: Young Dumb and Full of Rum
children.description: More dead-vert high-ball climbing on minor holds. Small seam crack towards top yields largest holds.

children.name: Cracked Lump
description: While there is a minor parking lot opposite the MS 300 entry ramp, getting away from this hairpin turn at one of the larger more visible parking lots further up-road or meters back adjacent to the river is advised. It is not advised to jeopardize access to the Garden by parking at the Illegal Parking lot on MS 300. It is indeed convenient to Big Fred, Azain, and Angry Grandma. And, as a walk-in this access still retains value. Parking here is unreasonable for the distance saved versus the consequence of losing climbing access to the Garden's many areas. En route to this acess point you will walk by Weigh Stop and Illegal Parking Wall. At the top of the sharp turn making the Lower Garden Access is the highly visable Illegal Parking Boulders: On the Yellow Brick Road, Oz and Off To See the Wizard. From here its uphill for a stretch before the extremly obvious Cracked Lump.

children.name: Trucker Belly (Working Off The)
children.description: Warm-up slab stepping off the raod onto ease.

children.name: CB Radio Warm-up
children.description: Another slab warm-up.

children.name: Biscuits and Gravy
children.description: Slab warm-up involving crack near top-out.

children.name: Allann's Truck Stop
children.description: Easy slab warm-up involving crack system.

children.name: Cracked Lump
children.description: Not much taller than most boulders of the Garden, Cracked Lump presents a very big formation in terms of its width and girth. Its front facing slab offers easy climbing and two practice cracks. Walking to its mouth entrance the climber is faced with a large hallway, with steep rock on one side and a paralleling slab. Some choices bouldering problems are presenting in the hallway, and a single bolted line with visible top-anchor bolts can be seen from the road. A single uncharted boulder is tucked in behind the formation, hidden from the road until you have walked past the Cracked Lump formation. The forest behind and around the Cracked Lump may in fact yield more boulders. More areas await adventurers heading farther up MS 300 as well...

children.name: Practice Crack
children.description: Not tall enough to lead, but a normally sunny spot to tinker with thin crack jams / gear.

children.name: Mouth
children.description: Good sit start problem utilizing steep wall to the climbers left at the Cracked Lump hallway entrance. Sliding downhill to the more pronounced arete is the Mouth Arete.

children.name: Mouth Arete
children.description: Sit start on downhill side, slapping both sides of sharp arete. Quality holds, can be dry and sunny when Garden is not.

children.name: Cracked Lump Crack
children.description: Sit start the crack awkwardly. Not awkward after first couple moves. Can go high ball with top-out as quality jamps and crimps connect to short slab.

children.name: Cracked Lump Project
children.description: Difficult sit start to steep face. High-ball, or may see bolts nearby Mental Jewelry.

children.name: 2nd Cracked Lump Project
children.description: Same concept as Cracked Lump Project, steep difficult line with no bolts currently. Landing in region stinks, necessitating bolts.

children.name: Mental Jewelry
children.description: Can be sit start. Difficult, technical, involving small intricate crimps, edges, slopers and minor feet. A fall may still put the leader back on a bad landing block, despite the bolts.

children.name: Back Against A Wall
children.description: Interesting sit start through steep moves utilizing distinct duck bill sloper.

children.name: In the Crack
children.description: Steep problem, using smaller in size crimps, edges and minor pockets.

children.name: Cracked Lump Stem
children.description: Good problem. Sit start is awkward. Stem moves from standing height to top-out.

children.name: Finger Trap
children.description: Avoiding ramp block to the right, a decent sit start through big holds problem tucked in before crack.

children.name: Middle Garden
description: Making your way to the Middle Garden you will be passing the parking lot Mile point 3.08, passing MS 210 (access road for Upper Garden) and parking at Mile point lot 3.3 or 3.4. Parking lot at 3.4 is not ideal, as it follows a sharp hair-turn, and is much smaller and less visible to on-coming logging trucks. The lot at mile 3.3 is larger, allows more space between the lot and the road and is the same walk length to Prince Alber and the entrance to the Middle Garden. Whether walking or driving, the head of Prince ALbert pokes up through the trees, with the Middle Garden Cliff-band looming over. Hop the roads ditch and scramble a hillside access in proximity to Prince ALber. A minor trail system presents around Prince ALber, but does not maintain or connect to other boulders of the Middle Garden. The Middle requires bushwhacking and in some cases boulder prep. Some boulders show signs of being climbed historically, but this area does not see the re-cleaning and coninuous climbing of the Lower Garden, or parts of the Upper.

children.name: Hidden Slab
children.description: Decient size for a warm-up slab, out of the way in location.

children.name: Grumpy Gus
children.description: Right side closer to Quality Arete, simular difficulty and nature to Hidden Slab.

children.name: Wolf Like Me
children.description: Left side prominent steep arete. Good holds and moves for size of boulder.

children.name: Y Control
children.description: Vert to slight low angle face next to arete. Slapping right edge brings down difficulty.

children.name: Easy Up, Easy Down
children.description: Beyond the descent and access ot Alber's single piece of jewelry (1 bolt anchor) for top-roping this line presents a work at it warm-up.

children.name: Jim Ward
children.description: Walking around Prince Alber counter-clockwise from Easy Up, Easy Down, the steepest most difficult portion of Prince Albert is encountered. Sit start or stand, steep terrain with small holds present difficulty that only eases at 8-10 feet off the deck.

children.name: Doug Malloy
children.description: Climbs right of Jim Ward, slightly more positive holds present slightly easier option through steepeness.

children.name: Fakir Musafar
children.description: Potentially one of the highest quality on the boulder, a steep arete presents slightly less difficulty than neighboring Doug Malloy and Jim Ward. With distinctive holds, this problem's difficulty retains through top-out.

children.name: Prince Alber Arete
children.description: While steepness is relieved compared to the rest of the problems, the holds of this problem aren't much bigger. This and other Prince Alber problems are relatively high-balls for the area.

children.name: Down in A Hole
children.description: Where the entry trail meets Prince ALber a large hole is presented adding 2-3 feet to the already tall Prince Albert. Problem retains difficulty despite less steepness than opposite portion of the boulder.

children.name: Deforestation
children.description: Sit start on the arete with distinctive sloper balls tensioning through semi-steep terrain. Not so positive slopers for top-out.

children.name: Screaming at A Wall
children.description: Sit start is awkward and non known to author. Stand starting into sheer wall from a minor hole below the wall makes for a dead vert edging and sloper problem. Slightly stiffer but simular to problems on Peter Brink's Itchy Balls Boulders' Vert Wall.

children.name: Too Slab To Be This Hard
children.description: Difficult slab problems of Font come to mind with this low angle, yet deceivingly difficlut problem started from a low squat or standing into boulder.

children.name: Young Folks
children.description: Awkward sit start but less than stellar stand start problem with a poor landing due to butt block.

children.name: Deforestation Arete
children.description: A poor landing takes away from an otherwise interesting steep problem.

children.name: Ya Ya Crack
children.description: Sit start, climbs jams in crack and holds outside of crack. Crux comes near top.

children.name: Ya Ya Steep Left
children.description: Sit start below left flank of middle bubble. Steep moves on challenging holds.

children.name: Ya Ya Steep Right
children.description: Sit start below right flank of middle bubble. Steep difficult moves.

children.name: No Piece of Cake
children.description: Primary problem of boulder. Sit start, postive holds end after start.

children.name: Ya Ya Warm-up
children.description: Almost a warm-up, as the angle turns to vert on this flank of the boulder.

children.name: Myrtle
children.description: Bit too short for quality, sit start below angle break, the problem ends too quickly.

children.name: Terrapin Traverse
children.description: A steep deer trail running against this flank of the boulder presents an interesting start low, end high and right finish traverse of the face. Landing is poor. This flank of the boulder faces away from the road and sun, towards the areas cliff band.

children.name: Snapping Backside
children.description: With your back to the path continuing onto Jaws and Terrapin Traverse to the left hand side, this backside short problem has a decent landing.

children.name: Jaws
children.description: Sit start below flank facing road. Good holds, good moves. Primary problem.

children.name: Fresh Tuna
children.description: Different sit start and mid holds than Jaws, this line runs up the left side from the same cave. Much less enduro-power than Jaws, as steepness ends faster.

children.name: Mackerel Stew
children.description: Correcting body position to stay left of the arete is half the problem beyond its sit start. Slopey not so positive holds to start.

children.name: Chopped Suey
children.description: Worst landing of boulder with small block to your back for sit start. This broad flank of Jaws boulder offers steepness and more positive holds, over a breaker of a landing.

children.name: Ahi Slab
children.description: After battling brush to stand below broad slab, stand start into minor edges and slopey holds, with divots and dimes for upper feet. A decently proud slab.

children.name: Quality High-ball
children.description: An opportune boulder in an opportune setting, yet quality high-ball is rarely clean? The Middle Garden holds a ton of potential for new and old Gardeners alike.

children.name: Chopped Liver Face
children.description: Very short squat start through sheer face to quick top-out.

children.name: Underlcing Arete
children.description: Simular to Chopped Liver Face in height, moving through obvious undercling.

children.name: Grand
children.description: Kick start onto lifted block transitioning past steepness into smallest holds of boulder, through the center flank. Sit start undone recently.

children.name: Eva Julie
children.description: Simular start to Grand, but the kick plate is higher, veering to relatively positive holds.
children.transcriptionNotes: Route ID replaced with route name, ID referenced to self, assuming previous route. Minor grammar correction.

children.name: No Easy Bail
children.description: Start on Eva Julie, veering drastically right to secondary roof provides a step-off opportunity in upper section, but difficulty retains.
children.transcriptionNotes: Route ID replaced with route name. V2+/3- grade will be simplified to V2/3.

children.name: Sweet Pea's Grand Adventure
children.description: Steep start with 2 exits, either staying with steepness through smallish holds up the center right of center flank, or a right traverse finish on semi-slopers.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: Below Grand
children.description: Steepish low roof. Never seen clean.

children.name: Jugs
children.description: Cultivated as a warm-up in a region with little cleaned below harder projects. Short.

children.name: Crystalline Mantle
children.description: Color of the rock is cool, the problem - not so crystalline. Short. Warm-up.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded.

children.name: Lawnmower Warm-up
children.description: Behind Lawnmower Man, an exposed arete makes for an easy warm-up.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded.

children.name: Motorcade of Silence
children.description: Stand into crimpy holds on a low angle. Decent warm-up.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded.

children.name: Prolonging the Scrub
children.description: Stand into wider stems and smaller holds than Motorcade of Silence on left flank.
children.transcriptionNotes: Route ID replaced with route name, ID referenced to self, assuming previous route. Given the direction provided (left) and topo, it's possible the topo / direction / route descriptions are incorrect.

children.name: Red Scoop
children.description: Hidden gem! With your back to the Upper Garden, a sit start through interesting holds with difficulty easing halfway through to a rounded slab top-out. Couple variants left and right off sit start.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: Red Slab
children.description: Around left of Red Scoop, this slab problem was crumbly but cleaned well.
children.transcriptionNotes: Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: 2nd Slab
children.description: Opposite side of boulder of Red Slab, but simular in nature, a low angle warm-up.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Route ID replaced with route name.

children.name: Hook
children.description: Amazing! An elusive and difficult to find problem. High off the deck, with manageable moves low through cruxy holds stumping most in the middle to high. High-ball!
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded.
Route placeholders were provided but not even usual "Not Yet Done" or "V?" were provided. Leaving here as ID placeholders.
Route placeholders were provided but not even usual "Not Yet Done" or "V?" were provided. Leaving here as ID placeholders.
Route placeholders were provided but not even usual "Not Yet Done" or "V?" were provided. Leaving here as ID placeholders.

Route placeholders were provided but not even usual "Not Yet Done" or "V?" were provided. Leaving here as ID placeholders. Clear gap of routes between this and 289. Unsure where those pages have gone.

children.name: Upper Garden
description: The earliest parking lot at mile point 3.08 is the ideal starting point for the Upper Garden. The walk from the parking lot at mile point 3.3 is no shorter and a lot less opportune. Either lots require walking a short distance uphill on the logging road MS 210. A single switchback at the entry loops around the bottom of the Uppers. 100 or so feet after the road bends back to perpendicular with the road below a minor pullout on the right hand side, and a series of large cut stumps on both sides of the road indicate the start of trailheads to the right hand side. If you've travelled MS 210 to a fork in the road you've gone too far. Where this fork is roughly close to Peter Brink's Itchy Balls Boulder, but there is no access trail and the area between the road and boulder tends to stay marshy.
children.transcriptionNotes: Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: Scratch and Spliff Traverse
children.description: Longish fun traverse starting at lowest point on climber's right side of steep face. An uber positive double jug (that has felt like it would break for 7+ years) sets up a biggish but easy move to a set of face holds and jug breaks at the lip. Traversing right to left on positive holds tends to take rehearsal (but onsighted regularly), to a rest with positive cracks and holds. From here top-out requires a few reachy moves on positive holds ending with easy mantle. Traverse can be reversed, starting at rest before top-out back to start. Ending the traverse and topping out various alternative points results in the much more difficult Scratch and Spliff.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected. Clear gap of routes between this and 283. Unsure where those pages have gone.

children.name: Scratch
children.description: Completing three quarters of the traverse, stopping prior to rest and topping out on semi-positive, semi-slopey holds on much steeper terain than Scratch and Spliff Traverse's top-out results in a quality gem. Can be trated as a separate problem with sit start on easy rest below top-out.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected. Route ID replaced with route name.

children.name: Spliff
children.description: After initial sit start moves of Scratch and Spliff Traverse, transitioning directly up creates stiffer test-piece on potentially the smallest holds of boulder's flank. Worst of landings on top-out.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected. Route ID replaced with route name.

children.name: Zig-Zag Papers
children.description: Same sit start to the first move as Scratch and Spliff Traverse, Scratch and Spliff, but then moving right, rounding the corner out of steepness onto low angle face, off of decent holds. Ends on a low-angle flank with balencey V0+/1- moves. Awkward position for pull-around move can create bad fall potential.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected. Route ID replaced with route name.

children.name: Roach Warm-up
children.description: Stand start with obvious holds where crack and breaks in the low-angle face occur. Positive holds up high can seep water. Ground block to the climber's right creates worse than should be landing on otherwise mellow face.
children.transcriptionNotes: Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: S and S Decent
children.description: Descent path for all problems this side of topping Scratch and Spliff, utilizing slick and mossy ground block. When wet, a large jug can be utilized to turn into rock and lower to ground block rather than jumping down.
children.transcriptionNotes: Minor grammar error assumed and corrected. Unsure what is meant by last sentence.

children.name: Stoned Age
children.description: Better landing and this problem would be a gem. Standing into edges and crack breaks, high feet unlocks holds crack to crack on vert to slightly steep face. Landing is hill of broken talus.

children.name: Crunch and Groove
children.description: Simular to Stoned Age, with smaller feet and hand holds, especially high up. Stiff.
children.transcriptionNotes: Route ID replaced with route name.

children.name: Happy Camper
children.description: Steep corner problem with only sit start for this flank. Holds on either side of arete to semi-positive top-out.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded.

children.name: Contrived Buddha
children.description: Steep corner with pure block landing. Sit start barely has enough room for most bodies. Sit start hits the arete immediately and stays with corner for opportune angle, slapping both sides of the arete.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: White Elephant
children.description: Squatish sit start with the right hand starting on gaston hold and left leg flexed out to start of Anicca. Longish moves break to break with minor intermediate holds. Minor toe flakes have snapped off this face.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Route ID replaced with route name.

children.name: Anicca
children.description: Hard project that was worked by the author during time spent with near problems. Steepest face with smallest holds at breaks, minor intermediates and useless underclings.
children.transcriptionNotes: Historical context separated.

children.name: Dukkha
children.description: Quality problem with the bitter end of the landings found on Contrived Buddha, White Elephant and Anicca. Problem can be entered into via Buddha's Belly's squat start or its own stiffer sit start. Mental crux at top involves mantle over worst of landing. Stepping off onto Buddha's Belly jug and turning out has been implemented for failed attempts.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Route ID replaced with route name.

children.name: Buddha's Belly
children.description: Squat start presents decent holds and quality moves veering slightly right, then back left to large positive jug presents the ending to a V1+ start. A few minor holds under a slight roof helps to mantle and gain feet on the ultra-positive jug. Above roof is a large hold-less slope with minor crimps, pocks and minimal friction. Traversing extreme left finishes easily on Anattā's slab finish.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Route ID replaced with route name.

children.name: Anattā
children.description: Easy warm-up starting low on the extreme left flank of the Buddha's Belly. Gainting a positive heel hook on the starting jug gains a low angle slab with holds to choose from. Fun. Can be transitioned into from Buddha's Belly and many of the holds from Buddha's Belly can be accessed and cleaned from this problem.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Route ID replaced with route name. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: Whorf
children.description: Area classic! From low set of positive holes, lower yourself into the chasm. Tensioning your body as not to butt flop on lower rock base is half the difficulty. Once the feet have gained the starting hand holds, the space becomes large enough to spot properly. Three or four moves into the problem the angle drastically turns over from super steep to slab. Walking into the slab grovel and top-out can actually be deceptively difficult. While rest form the cave portion and positive holds are gained, the feet are minor and can be slick walking out the V0 finish.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: Klingon Off A Leash
children.description: Whorf's start. After lip is gained, traverse extreme left on positive edges and crimps on the slab side of the lip. This variant finish ends up having two or three different ways of trackling slab, from edge to edge, all different from Whorf's normal top-out, but never harder.
children.transcriptionNotes: Abbreviation expanded. Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: Harder Whorf
children.description: Lowering further into the cave and even to the climber's left towards the light presents a more difficult cave problem than the starting two sets of jugs low on the extreme right of the cave. The lowest portion of this cave gets that much more wet, mossy and slick. Moving low, the holds get smaller and have been known to flake off. The fall is manageable because the cave is an almost chimney-able size crack.
children.transcriptionNotes: Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: Ragnorök
children.description: Project needed cleaning. This flank is easily visible from Baseball, en route to Scratch and Spliff, Clearcut High-ball ect... Never seen clean since 2001 and as of 2011.

children.name: Apocolypse
children.description: Project needed cleaning climbing out of a cave in the brush. The landing will clear out as it is a series of built up brush and debris.

children.name: Smoke and Wine (Will Save)
children.description: Slab to vert project needed cleaning. This flank is not readily seen. If you travel from Pumpkin to the Buddha's Belly portion of Scratch and Spliff you will pass it. Other than Ragnorök(sp.)'s cut of exposure and this cut of exposure, the Armageddon is covered in grass, dirt, moss and debris.
children.transcriptionNotes: Minor grammar error assumed and corrected.

children.name: Last Caress
children.description: Right flank of slab, next to Smoke and Wine. Closer to other portion of exposed problems on Armageddon Boulder.
children.transcriptionNotes: Route ID replaced with route name.

children.name: Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels
Pints of Guinness Make You Strong
I Don't Want To Be (Sam) I Am
In For a Penny, In For a Pound
